Plant emergency procedures are maintained onsite. WTP personnel are trained to take action to control a minor release. Trained responding staff will attempt to control a release within their capability. However, in the event the release is beyond the control of plant staff, they would immediately call 911. 
Planned Changes to Improve Safety
The WTP planned changes to improve safety include increased signage in process areas and coordinate more robust onsite drills with local responders.

An authorization and permit program for hot work operations near or around the regulated chlorine process has been implemented by the WTP. Contractors performing maintenance or repair on or adjacent to the chlorine process are instructed in hazards of materials onsite, and documentation is maintained on contractor understanding of training provided as described in the Plan. Emphasis is placed on knowing how to respond and evacuate in the event of an emergency. The WTP chlorine system technology is not confidential and information regarding the process is available for review in the RMP/PSM Plan.
Five-Year Accident History
There have been no accidental releases within the past 5 years from the chlorine covered processes that resulted in deaths, injuries, evacuations, sheltering-in-place, property damage, or environmental damage. 
Emergency Response Program
The RMP Emergency Response Plan for the WTP includes the following elements:
	Procedures for informing the public and local emergency response agencies about accidental releases
	Documentation of proper first aid and emergency medical treatment to treat accidental human exposures
	Procedures and measures for emergency response compliance after a reportable accidental release of a regulated substance
	Procedures for the use of emergency response equipment and for its inspection, testing, and maintenance

A Hazard Review/PHA was completed for this (RMP)/Process Safety Management (PSM) Plan that documents the process and findings to minimize or eliminate hazards, to mitigate consequences of hazards of any releases or other unplanned events and reduce the likelihood of exposure to chlorine. 
Written procedures and information have been developed, implemented, and maintained for each hazardous process, including steps for each operating phase, operating limits, safety and health considerations, and safety systems and their functions. All employees involved in working with and around the chlorine system are trained annually in process and safety procedures, including emergency response.
The mechanical integrity of chlorine process equipment is documented and maintained through maintenance, inspection, and testing programs. In addition, a Management of Change program has been established to ensure proper review of a proposed change to the chlorine system.
A pre-startup safety review is performed on new or modified processes to ensure that equipment and construction meet design specifications, procedures and training have been implemented, and hazard analysis recommendations have been resolved.
A Compliance Audit Program has also been implemented. The objective of this self-evaluation program is to ensure that a strong RMP is maintained, implemented, and followed by appropriate personnel. Staff have developed a formal, documented system to manage incident investigations and follow up. Each incident from a covered process that resulted in deaths, injuries, evacuations, sheltering-in-place, property damage, or environmental damage will be investigated, and an incident investigation report filed in the RMP.

Lake Hefner WTP Executive Summary Feb 2022

40 CFR Part 68.155
Lake Hefner Water Treatment Plant (WTP) has adopted this Risk Management Program (RMP) to implement 40 Code of Federal Regulations (CFR) 68, the federal requirements regulating risk management of extremely hazardous chemicals. This Program will help prevent the occurrence of, or minimize the consequences of, a catastrophic release by implementing policies and procedures for the management of process hazards in start-up, operation, inspection, maintenance, and other requirements addressed in the federal standard.
This Executive Summary includes information required under 40 CFR 68.155.
Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies
The City of Oklahoma City Utilities Department implements a scheduled preventive maintenance program, including inspection and testing, to minimize the potential for accidental releases. Standard Operating Procedures (SOPs) have been reviewed and revised to enable employees to perform their work safely and efficiently and provide immediate corrective response to any accidents.
Lake Hefner WTP staff are trained to respond in the event of a chemical release incident. Emergency response to accidental releases is also coordinated with the Oklahoma City Police and Fire Departments and State and Local Emergency Response Centers.
Stationary Sources and Regulated Substances
Lake Hefner WTP utilizes chlorine (regulated substance) as a disinfectant in the drinking water treatment process. 
General Accidental Release Prevention Program and Chemical-Specific Prevention Steps
A Process Hazard Analysis (PHA) and written process safety information have been developed to enable personnel to identify and understand hazards posed by processes involving extremely hazardous chemicals. Process safety information includes chlorine information, technology of the process information, and equipment information.
